About Us | LA Champagne CPA 4911 Bennington Ave BR, LA lac@laccpa.com Home About Us Our Team Services Contact Pay Invoice Client Login Home About Us Our Team Services Contact Pay Invoice About Us Home About Us Who We Are Our Profile L. A. Champagne & Co., L.L.P. traces its origin to 1919 when Mr. L.A. Champagne began practicing as a public accountant in Baton Rouge. He developed a commitment to professional competence that has been the pillar of our success ever since. We are proud to be accounting professionals who provide quality service. Our partners and professional staff live, work, and raise their children in the greater Baton Rouge community, and strive to contribute to its continued success. We are a full-service accounting firm that provides services in the following areas: Audit services, including governmental audits Reviews and compilations Individual income tax return prep and planning Business income tax return prep and planning Non-profit income tax return prep and planning Bookkeeping services Payroll services Business consulting Software consulting Our professional staff are accounting graduates of accredited universities, and the firm encourages all professional staff to successfully complete the CPA examination, which many have done. All professional staff attend continuing professional education each year to ensure that they stay current with ever changing rules and regulations. Combined with on-the-job training and experience, this education allows our professionals to be efficient and effective in a broad range of services. Our Services “At L.A. Champagne, our clients come first, and we strive for excellence through quality service.” KIM SANDERS PARTNER Our Team Kim Sanders, CPA, MBA Managing Partner ksanders@laccpa.com WAYNE C. DUSSEL, CPA, CFE Partner wdussel@laccpa.com NEAL FORTENBERRY, CPA Partner nfortenberry@laccpa.com JONATHAN T. Submit your reservation request for your group here: Group Reservation Inquiry Events NON-PRIVATE COCKTAIL PARTIES Our non-private cocktail parties take place alongside our regular service and reserve a designated section of the dining room. We offer the bar by consumption or with an open bar package and food stations. Event Inquiry form below! PRIVATE PARTIES Host your next private event with us at Rouge! Booking our indoor dining room closes down all indoor and outdoor seating for an entirely exclusive private event. Our indoor dining room can host up to 40 people seated or up to 80 for a cocktail party. Event bookings are usually three hours. Our space lends itself better to a cocktail event with passed hors d’oeuvres and stationed lunch or dinner. However, for smaller seated events, we can offer a cocktail hour with hors d'oeuvres followed by a family-style sit-down meal. photo by @briancngo *    *    *   *   * We can host indoor group dining reservations alongside our regular service for up to 14 people, select time slots are available for booking with one of our family-style prix fixe menu options. Please visit our Group Dining tab for more information. It is governed by a Board of Directors comprising individuals from the arts, business and professional fields. Each Board member serves, along with other volunteers, on one or more board committees addressing specific roles, including Executive, Finance, Nomination and Governance, Development, Facility and Future Planning/Community Engagement. These collectively support the affairs of the Contemporary Art Gallery at planning and operational levels. Denis Walz, President Justine A. Vin Rouge Wine Bar and Tasting Room - About Us Skip to content Account Your Account Log In Cart 0 items: $0.00 Close Shopping Cart Item was successfully added to your cart Qty Item Description Price Total Subtotal $0.00 View Cart Home Menus Search Our Wines Reds Whites Rosé Bubbles Aperitifs & Digestifs Beer About Us Reserve Your Table Neighbors Club Events Vin Rouge Wine Bar and Tasting Room Home About Us About Vin Rouge “ We are opening up an approachably bougie wine bar...everyone wants to feel fancy without feeling out of place. We wanted to have a cool, boutique wine bar, with wines and high-end beers. ” — Jenn Feinstein in Business Denver Owner Jenn Feinstein has been in the hospitality industry for over 20 years, starting at one of The Ritz Carlton’s flagship properties. Before moving to Denver with husband and partner Jarrett Feinstein , Jenn oversaw one of the first wineries in Santa Barbara County, Sunstone Vineyards & Winery. Over several years they were able to visit tasting rooms and vineyards together along the entire west coast, meeting with winemakers, vineyard owners, tasting room staff, and the people maintaining the vines, learning together the labor and love it takes to get the grapes from soil to bottle. At Vin Rouge, you get to choose where your heart feels home… the living room, dining room, or the bar. We actually appealed to the city to reduce our occupancy level because we wanted the space to feel comfortable and not crowded. The design is purposeful and the building was carefully chosen to reflect the warmth of a historical building with original hardwoods and exposed brick, with modern but classic furniture and fixtures. It’s meant to feel luxurious but still approachable… like our wine. Our wine is unique and not something you will find on the wine list at your favorite restaurant or in markets, but there is something for every taste available – we will help you find it. We hope through this method that our guests that may feel intimidated by the hundreds of labels on store shelves will now have the confidence to purchase on their own. Get to know your tastes and articulate your palate without anyone "winesplaining". Read more about Jenn and Jarrett's journey to open Vin Rouge in Voyage Denver , or reserve your table and ask them when you come in and enjoy one of their lovely wines or crafted beers. About Us - Champagne Fire Truck - Mobile Champagne Bar Skip to main content MENU MENU Home About Us Blog Events Upcoming Events Gallery Testimonials Contact Us Get in Touch Today 07736 815 413 Published by gudideas on 06 th January 2020 , About Us , Updated on 10 th December 2020 Vintage 1972 Champagne Fire Truck About Us Champagne Fire Truck is built on vintage, heritage and experience to create unforgettable moments for you to enjoy. Learn More Creating Unrivalled “Instagrammable” Moments Committed To Creating Unforgettable Experiences Our journey in the food and drink industry started many moons ago, working in food development for globally recognised brands such as Fortnum & Mason, M&S and Waitrose. With a growing interest in the explosion of fresh savoury food in the event catering industry, Belistore was born. Belistore has continued to grow in popularity, providing delicious, home cooked goodies straight from the oven to events across the country. In tandem with the success of  belistore and with our passion for bringing truly unique experiences to the industry, we took on a new business venture – say hello to the Champagne Fire Truck! Dating back to 1972, our British Leyland AEC fire engine has been lovingly restored to retain many original features, while granting it a new lease of life as a high-end Champagne bar. With original working sirens, blue lights, chrome detailing and iconic red paintwork, the Champagne Fire Truck retains it’s original character, yet with a quirky twist! The side lockers – once home to hose reels and kit, now house fridges brimming with Champagne.  A stunning bar, constructed from authentic French riddling racks is topped with a section of the fire truck’s original water tank, while a gazebo consisting of a ladder frame and stunning red canopy offers shelter from the elements. Clients can enjoy a service bespoke to their requirements, including their choice of Champagnes, bringing both authenticity and originality to any occasion. Find out more about us and our events . A Taste Of The Finest French Bubbly Touring The Champagne Region To keep our promise of providing clients with a taste of the very best Champagnes, it was only fair to set off on a tour of the French province. From strolling through the vineyards in which the grapes to transform into Moët & Chandon are grown, to visiting the renowned Hotel Chandon, we travelled far and wide to handpick our favourite fizz. We spent time with the creators of the world’s most exquisite Champagnes, such as Bollinger and Taittinger, gaining an understanding of what it takes to achieve such a delicate taste. From vine to bottle, we were lucky enough to get involved in each step the process and even better, there was a fair share of sampling along the way! Team — Pressoir 0 Skip to Content Pressoir Club ▼ The Press Videos At Home Session Recordings THIRST Classes La Paulée 2021 Virtual Seminar Recordings La Fête du Champagne 2021 Virtual Seminars Join The Club Wine Experiences Wine Consulting Wine Festivals ▼ La Paulée La Fête du Champagne La Tablée New York Convivio del Vino Contact Us ▼ Contact Us In The News Team Upcoming Events Open Menu Close Menu Pressoir Club ▼ The Press Videos At Home Session Recordings THIRST Classes La Paulée 2021 Virtual Seminar Recordings La Fête du Champagne 2021 Virtual Seminars Join The Club Wine Experiences Wine Consulting Wine Festivals ▼ La Paulée La Fête du Champagne La Tablée New York Convivio del Vino Contact Us ▼ Contact Us In The News Team Upcoming Events Open Menu Close Menu Folder: Pressoir Club ▼ Back The Press Videos At Home Session Recordings THIRST Classes La Paulée 2021 Virtual Seminar Recordings La Fête du Champagne 2021 Virtual Seminars Join The Club Wine Experiences Wine Consulting Folder: Wine Festivals ▼ Back La Paulée La Fête du Champagne La Tablée New York Convivio del Vino Folder: Contact Us ▼ Back Contact Us In The News Team Upcoming Events About Us Daniel Johnnes Founder Bio Edouard Bourgeois Wine Director Bio Jaime Dutton Executive Director Bio Nikita Malhotra Head Sommelier Bio Max Goldberg Liu Director of Communications Bio Justine Puaud Director of Client Relations & Producer Liaison Bio Astrid Breggia Marketing Manager & Event Coordinator Bio Sally Johnnes Accounting Back to Team Daniel Johnnes founder Daniel Johnnes’s love for French wine and culture was born early in life, thanks to a teenage trip on the advisement of his mother. A born and bred New Yorker, Daniel visited France for the first time in 1974 and immediately fell in love with the language, cuisine, wine and culture. This launched a life that took him through the great vineyards and kitchens of France, the restaurant cellars and dining rooms of his hometown, and ultimately to creating a business designed to share his love of French wine and culture with fellow Americans, which in turn has earned him two medals of honor from the French government for his career: the Chevalier de l’Ordre du Mérite Agricole (2016) and Chevalier de l’Ordre du Mérite (2023). A Dedication to Service After graduating from college with a BA in French, Daniel returned to France to work in the kitchens of Guy Savoy in Paris followed by a stint in the Landes region of Southwestern France. When he returned to New York, he decided the hospitality and service that defined the front of house roles was where he was meant to be. This decision led him to Le Regence, where a young Daniel Boulud had recently assumed the position of Executive Chef. In 1985, Daniel joined the team opening Montrachet in Tribeca, which won a Wine Spectator Grand Award and quickly became “New York’s finest wine restaurant,” according to that same publication. During that time, he began to curate wine dinners, hosting great winemakers from Burgundy and beyond. These dinners led Daniel to bring Burgundy’s acclaimed La Paulée de Meursault to New York in 2000, emulating the celebration at the end of harvest by presenting a week-long series of events to celebrate the wines and winemakers of Burgundy. During his 20 years as the Wine Director at Montrachet and Drew Nieporent’s Myriad Restaurant Group, Daniel also started an import company featuring a curated selection of French wines, some never before imported to the United States. His first discoveries were from little known appellations such as Gaillac and Saint Pourçain. Over the years, he represented some of the most famous estates in Burgundy and beyond, including, among others, Domaine Georges Roumier, Domaine des Comtes Lafon, Domaine Roulot, Domaine Mugneret-Gibourg, Domaine Clusel-Roch, and Domaine de la Grange des Pères. In 2005, Johnnes reunited with Daniel Boulud to become the corporate Wine Director for Chef Boulud’s Dinex Group. Their restaurant empire includes DANIEL, DB Bistro, Bar Boulud, Boulud Sud, Le Gratin, Joji, Le Pavillon and Epicerie Boulud in New York as well as locations in Florida, Montreal, Toronto, Singapore, Dubai, the Bahamas, and at sea on Celebrity Beyond. He also manages the wine program at American Express’s new Centurion New York lounge in the One Vanderbilt building. Dubbed “the dean of American Sommeliers” by Jay McInerney in the The Wall Street Journal, Daniel is also dedicated to mentoring a new generation of sommeliers. In 2021, he created the Sommelier Scholarship Fund, a 501(c)3 organization that offers educational experiences to rising wine professionals to learn firsthand about the people, culture, winemaking, and terroir that so inspired Daniel during his first trips to France. Awards & Acclaim Daniel’s career is studded with industry awards, including the highest honor bestowed on a wine professional in the United States - the James Beard Foundation’s Outstanding Wine and Spirits Professional of the Year, which he received in 2006. He was also named the Wine and Spirits Professional of the Year by Santé in 2000 and was honored as the nation's top sommelier by the James Beard Foundation in 1995, receiving the Outstanding Wine Service Award. Daniel’s honors from the French Republic recognize his outstanding services to the sector of agriculture and the furtherance of French culture overall, and are the highest tiers of national merit other than the French Légion d’Honneur. In 2018, Daniel received his third James Beard Award when he was honored as “Who’s Who of Food and Beverage in America.” Rajat Parr and Jordan Mackay, in Secrets of the Sommeliers (TenSpeed Press, 2010), describe the “career paths of America’s four pioneering sommeliers (Larry Stone, Kevin Zraly, Daniel Johnnes and Fred Dame): “Stone, the wine genius; Zraly, the wine teacher; Johnnes, the inspirer; and Dame, the administrator and motivator: together they mentored a generation.” Today, in his role as founder of Pressoir, Daniel continues his mission to inspire by presenting the finest wine festivals, events and unique experiences, wine consulting, and an exclusive club. In addition to La Paulée, Daniel and the Pressoir team created La Fête du Champagne with wine writer and Champagne expert Peter Liem to educate consumers and promote the wines of Champagne, and La Tablée, an event celebrating the wines of the Northern and Southern Rhône Valley. Through extensive relationships and long careers in wine, Daniel and his team have developed a comprehensive network of producers throughout France’s revered wine regions, ensuring they have their finger on the pulse of the market and are ready to celebrate and share French fine wine and culture as it continues to shine. Back to Team Edouard Bourgeois Wine Director As Wine Director for Pressoir, Edouard Bourgeois shapes the many individual events that bring to life the organization’s mission to showcase the wine and culture of France. Overseeing the themes, locations and culinary pairings of the U.S. events, Bourgeois is instrumental in the Pressoir guest experience, bringing his expertise in French wine to settings large and small. Bourgeois came by his love of wine honestly. Born and raised in Champagne, France, his exposure to the great wines of his home country played a vital role in defining his career in fine wine. Through the hospitality business, he learned how to communicate his passion and knowledge to others. Driven by this passion, he landed himself a position as a sommelier at the Parisian Palace Hôtel de Crillon’s Restaurant Les Ambassadeurs. Here, under the direction of David Biraud, who was named Best Sommelier France in 2002, Bourgeois’s fascination with wine began to flourish. In 2005, he won first prize at the French National Trophée Mumm for student sommeliers, and caught the attention of lead judge and chef sommelier of the Les Crayères, Philippe Jamesse, who offered him a position upon graduation. He proceeded to work beside Jamesse for three years, honing the complexity of his palate and developing his expertise in the field. Bourgeois moved to New York City in 2008 where he secured himself the role of sommelier at Restaurant DANIEL, Chef Daniel Boulud’s eponymous culinary temple, a position he held for five years. He was then promoted to head sommelier and wine buyer for Restaurant Café Boulud, the sister property to Restaurant Daniel in the iconic Upper East Side Manhattan. After three years, he moved back to France to work closely with the winemaking team of the illustrious Domaine Lapierre, pioneer winery in the natural wine world in Villie-Morgon for the 2017 harvest. Today, he splits his time between the U.S. and France, overseeing the wine programs for the Dinex group restaurants, while also looking after the needs of the Pressoir Wine Club members and curating bespoke wine tours of France’s wine regions for small groups, visiting winemakers in their domaine, and thereby ensuring he stays perpetually connected to the two great loves that have shaped his life - wine and France. Back to Team Jaime Dutton Executive Director When Jaime Dutton assumed the position of executive director of Pressoir in 2007, it was the culmination of a journey that arguably began at age 11 with a visit to France and a small sip of wine. That early exposure to French wine and culture charted the course of her professional life, making her role of growing the Pressoir organization and its portfolio of seminal wine festivals and experiences a natural extension of her personal passions. Dutton’s bona fides in all things French have been earned through achieving a BA in French from University of Pennsylvania, during which she studied at La Sorbonne; earning her Masters Degree in the International Wine Trade from the University of Dijon, for which she was based in Beaune at the heart of Burgundy; serving as the Export Sales Manager of Maison Champy, one of Burgundy’s boutique negociants, where she established the brand in the New York market as well as in Europe and Asia. Dutton further honed her expertise by cycling and dining her way around France, exploring beautiful and remote corners of the country, visiting vineyards and choosing wines with sommeliers at the top tables in France and developing hospitality skills as a bike tour guide. It was Maison Champy that served as Dutton’s bridge to Daniel Johnnes, who was the New York importer at the time. In 2001, she attended La Paulée for the first time and discovered the serious Burgundy collecting scene in New York. Before returning to the U.S. in 2006, Dutton also explored the wines of Spain, spending two years in Madrid as the Export Director for Bodegas Riojanas (Rioja) and Bodegas Torreduero (Toro). However, it was her native country and her love of Burgundy that ultimately drew her home. As part of the Pressoir executive team, Dutton has sought to build on the success of La Paulée, expanding the festival beyond New York, and creating new festivals such as La Fête du Champagne and La Tablée, through which she seeks to create experiences for wider audiences to discover a lifelong passion through a simple sip of wine. Back to Team Nikita Malhotra Head sommelier Nikita Malhotra was born and raised in New York City and went to Rudolf Steiner School, a Waldorf School. This education informed her about biodynamic farming, which imbued her early career in the wine world with a purpose to seek out sustainable and responsible vignerons. During high school she started working at an academic bookstore and quickly knew she wanted to major in Philosophy once she got to Goucher College outside Baltimore. After 6 years of working at independent bookstores, she realized that perhaps her dream of owning a bookstore might not come to fruition. Wishful thinking of culinary school led to availability for a wine course and from there a love of the hospitality industry. At the age of 25 she became the General Manager and Wine Director of Tangled Vine, a wine bar with around 150 selections of all organic or biodynamic from the old world. After a year she joined the wine team at Tribeca Grill, working under David Gordon and being part of a Wine Spectator Grand Award winning program. David Gordon inspired her love of Grenache and an appreciation for Rhone wine. Five year later she found herself at Momofuku, as the Head Sommelier at Wayo. With the pandemic she shifted to retail and consulting and in 2021 came back to Momofuku as the Beverage Manager for Ko. During her tenure the list had grown with a focus on Burgundy and Champagne. She has been recognized as New York’s best Sommelier by the Michelin Guide in 2022 and the list won the Grand Prix Star Wine List Award for New York City in 2023. Back to Team Max Goldberg Liu Director of Communications In the words of Daniel Johnnes, Max Goldberg Liu “is Brooklyn born with the soul of a Frenchman. Maybe even a Burgundian.” Some of this may have been achieved thanks to a relationship with the Johnnes family going back to early childhood and a trip to Burgundy and Alsace with Johnnes at the age of 13 as a friend of Johnnes’ eldest son. A BA in French from Bowdoin College and a year spent at the University of Western Brittany as an English language assistant further honed his fluency in French language and culture and interest in wine, which led him to begin working with Johnnes in 2012. Over the past 10-plus years, Goldberg Liu has developed his proficiency in French wine from the ground up, initially managing Johnnes’ import portfolio, working two harvests in Burgundy, and traveling and tasting extensively throughout France’s wine regions, while helping organize dozens of editions of Pressoir’s wine festivals, La Paulée, La Fête du Champagne, and La Tablée, along with Pressoir’s ongoing programming. These experiences have informed Goldberg Liu’s role as Pressoir's Director of Communications and as a trip leader for the Sommelier Scholarship Fund. He is dedicated to translating French wine culture and the passionate work of the winemakers to an expanding American audience, with a particular focus on making old world domaines more accessible to a new generation of wine consumers. Back to Team Justine Puaud Director of Client Relations & Producer Liaison Justine was born and raised in France, in the Loire Valley region. Like many French children she often got a sip of wine in her parent’s glass during dinner time. But her passion for wine really grew when, at 23 years old, she went to Dijon for a business school interview. She spent 2 days in Burgundy driving around the vineyards with her father and that stuck with her. Despite Burgundy leaving an unforgettable impression, she moved to Bordeaux and got an MBA in Marketing and Management of Fine Wine. Thanks to this international program, she acquired a depth of knowledge in the wine and spirits trade from all over the world and an understanding of cultural differences related to business. During her time in Bordeaux, she worked as a Marketing and Communication Assistant for the Wine Syndicate of Saint-Emilion. There she learned about the right bank of Bordeaux, met fantastic winemakers and worked on the production of important French wine festivals such as Vinexpo Bordeaux, Bordeaux Fête le Vin and the Saint-Emilion Jazz Festival. Later, she joined a marketing and design agency specialized in wine and spirits as a Business Development Executive. There she spent her time working on marketing strategies, branding and storytelling for innovative wine estates, as well as prestigious Champagne and Cognac houses. In 2015 Justine moved to New York City and worked as a Marketing and Sales Associate for Acker Merrall & Condit, oldest wine shop in America and a leading wine auction house. She remembers fondly her first auction there, it was the best wine tasting she’d ever attended and she quickly understood that New York was a special place to live and discover some of the best wines in the world. In addition to the auctions, she had the chance to be part of exclusive rare wine dinners with unique wine selections from the likes of LaLa’s, Domaine de la Romanee Conti, and Biondi Santi. When presented with the opportunity to work with Daniel Johnnes and La Paulée, she asked her husband “what do you think?”. She saw stars in his eyes and understood. An integral part of the team since 2016, she is proud to be part of the production of the best wine festivals in the world. Bringing people together is what she loves about her job and what she is committed to! She recently moved back to France to get closer to her family but also the winemakers as she is living in Burgundy. She can’t wait to welcome you to France and show you her beautiful country! If you want to travel with Pressoir.wine, she is your right contact. Back to Team Astrid Breggia Event Coordinator Growing up in a household where the most memorable times were spent around a dinner table, Astrid gained an understanding of the importance of food and wine early on in life. Her upbringing sparked a passion and familial connection to both food and wine. Astrid spent her childhood visiting the local Fine Wines shop in her home town of Providence, Rhode Island, with her father; learning about different wines from small importers all over the world. After visiting the South of France for several weeks in 2022, Astrid evolved her interest in drinking and appreciating wines, to a spirit of curiosity in viticulture. She now regularly travels to expand her knowledge of wine and delve further into her experience with food. Astrid does not only enjoy eating adventurous and spectacular foods, but she also has a passion for cooking, which goes hand-in-hand with her excitement for wine. After graduating from American University in Washington, D.C. with a degree in Education and philosophy in 2021, she moved to New York in the search for a profession which combined her passions and professional goals; she found this at Pressoir. Since then, she has continued her dedication to learning about wine, gaining new experiences in the industry, and has even started learning French. Olivier Reynaud & Paul Rogalski Part of Calgary's History L ess than a ten-minute drive from downtown and on the Bow River, Rouge occupies, the historic Cross House in Inglewood. Inglewood is Calgary’s oldest neighbourhood, established adjacent to Fort Calgary in 1875. 9th Avenue South East, formerly named Atlantic Avenue, became the Calgary’s first authentic main street. Today, Inglewood is a vibrant, eclectic and ever-evolving arts and culture district with more than one hundred shops, boutiques and eateries. Built in 1891 by A.E. Cross, the Brewery House was home to the Cross family for decades and is now designated as a Calgary, Municipal and Alberta Provincial Heritage Site. Cross was one of the West’s most prominent cattlemen. In 1892 he founded the Calgary Brewing and Malting Co., the first brewing company in western Canada. He was one of the city’s “Big Four”, one of the original founders of The Calgary Stampede The Owners ■      ■      ■ O ur very personable owners Olivier Reynaud and Chef Paul Rogalski met in the mid-90s. They discovered mutual respect for each other’s professional abilities and experience, and a common dream of using their vast restaurant experience to create their own fine dining establishment in Calgary. The dream was for a restaurant that would showcase the best cuisine and service that Calgary had ever experienced by tapping into their cumulative 38 years of international experience and provide them with the opportunity to be really chatty with their patrons! Olivier and Paul have independently cultivated their skills and culinary perspective in nine different countries. They knew if they could take the best in service and food preparation from their experiences, they could dazzle patrons, food critics and food writers, alike. They have. In May of 2001 Olivier and Paul combined their tremendous experience to create The Cross House Restaurant, and in April 2003 introduced us to ROUGE – At The Cross House. Since the formation of their partnership, they have enjoyed outstanding reviews. It’s more than just the critics who are taking notice, though. Calgarians are making ROUGE a part of their Calgary culinary scene. Vin Rouge Wine Bar and Tasting Room - Menus Skip to content Account Your Account Log In Cart 0 items: $0.00 Close Shopping Cart Item was successfully added to your cart Qty Item Description Price Total Subtotal $0.00 View Cart Home Menus Search Our Wines Reds Whites Rosé Bubbles Aperitifs & Digestifs Beer About Us Reserve Your Table Neighbors Club Events Vin Rouge Wine Bar and Tasting Room Home Menus Vin Rouge Menus please click on each menu below as they all have unique links wines by the glass & bottle happy hour flight of the week flight of the month beer & non-alcoholic beverages nibbles current flight[s] September Flight of the Month - Willamette Valley Legends The Willamette Valley earned its reputation as America’s Burgundy thanks to a handful of pioneers in the 1960s and 70s. Families like the Ponzis, Sokol Blossers, and Adelsheims believed Oregon’s cool climate could coax elegance out of Pinot Noir — and history proved them right. The first vines planted here were Pinot Noir, Riesling, and Chardonnay, with Pinot quickly becoming the Valley’s signature. Today, Willamette is home to more than two-thirds of Oregon’s wineries, and Pinot Noir remains the star, flanked by Chardonnay, Riesling, and an increasing wave of sparkling wines that rival Champagne. Riesling has always been part of the region’s DNA, showing both crisp, dry precision and late-harvest opulence when botrytis makes its rare appearance. What makes Willamette extraordinary is its mosaic of nested AVAs, each defined by soils, slopes, and wind. Dundee Hills produces supple, red-fruit driven Pinots that showcase grace and finesse. The Laurelwood District, where Ponzi crafts its Chardonnay, is defined by basalt-based loess soils that yield wines with energy, minerality, and bright citrus tension. Yamhill-Carlton, home to Domaine Roy & Fils, is prized for ancient marine sedimentary soils that gift Pinot Noir with darker fruit, rich structure, and age-worthiness. In contrast, Eola-Amity Hills, one of Argyle’s sparkling strongholds, is cooled by ocean breezes funneled through the Van Duzer Corridor, resulting in wines with precision, freshness, and lifted aromatics. To the north, Elk Cove’s Rieslings remind us that this valley nurtures more than Pinot — late harvest bottlings bring golden-hued richness balanced by electric acidity, a style unique to the region’s long autumns. Together, these regions form a patchwork of character that makes the Willamette Valley one of the most exciting and versatile wine landscapes in the world. past flight[s] 2025 August Flight of the Month - Orixe Sotelo, Spanish wines thriving in Sonoma Gustavo & Jackie Sotelo are the proprietors behind Orixe Sotelo, a brand founded in Sonoma, California in 2019. Orixe [o-REE-shay] is a Galician word from Latin ‘origo’ meaning: ‘beginning, source, birth, origin’. The name Sotelo originates in the coastal mountains of Galicia, Spain. O.S. is the lens through which they aspire to expand upon California’s wine culture, specifically through the use of Spanish grape varieties. They have a strong vision for their future in California - a state that is primed for a renaissance of these cultivars and wine expressions. 8/26 through 8/30 - Summer Doesn’t Clock Out if Albariño’s on the Table When the nights start getting cooler but you’re not ready to let go of summer, Albariño’s got your back. This week’s Flight of the Week brings three styles of Spain’s ultimate sunshine grape: Attis 'Xión' – juicy peach, crisp citrus, and a salty sea breeze finish. Columna 'Granito' – more floral and mineral, like lemon zest over wet stone. And Orixe Sotelo 'Nebola' – a California riff with added texture and ripe pear vibes. Three pours, endless reminders that summer isn’t over until you say so. 8/20 through 8/23 - Summer Flower Day, a conversation about Biodynamics WHAT ARE BIODYNAMICS? The idea behind root days, fruit days, leaf days, and flower days was inspired by Rudolf Steiner, an Austrian philosopher who defined biodynamic farming for the 20th century. However, the focus on the moon and how it affects life on earth goes back farther than that: 1st century Roman naturalist Pliny the Elder said the moon ‘replenishes the earth; when she approaches it, she fills all bodies, while, when she recedes, she empties them.’ ORGANIC VS BIODYNAMIC VS NATURAL VS VEGAN Organic wine is made from grapes grown without synthetic fertilizers, herbicides, and pesticides. Biodynamic farmers view their farm or vineyard as one solid organism – a self-sustaining ecosystem. Natural wine is made with hand-picked organically or biodynamically grown grapes that were never exposed to to pesticides or herbicides. Vegan wine uses plant-based or synthetic alternatives for certain processes. 8/12 through 8/16 - Vin de Jardin en Fête [Garden Party Wine] Our Vin de Jardin en Fête flight is pure alfresco joy, a celebration of sunshine in the glass. Begin in Hungary with a crisp, zesty Furmint, all green apple and citrus blossom. Drift to across the Adriatic to Italy for a Vermentino blend that's bright, herbal, and kissed with Mediterranean salinity with a touch of texture from the kiss of Chardonnay. Glide across the Mediterranean Sea to the lavender-scented air of southern Frnace with a pale, elegant Provence rosé, whispering of strawberries and late summer evenings. This is a garden party you'll want to linger at all summer long. 8/05 through 8/10 - Italian Wine Holiday Imagine this…you’re on a once-in-a lifetime Italian holiday—sunbathing on the beaches of Puglia, sipping crisp, aromatic Fiano with sand between your toes. Then when it gets too hot you slowly meander north to Piedmont, where Barbera flows generously at every trattoria, bright and juicy enough to make you forget you have any responsibilities. And finally, because you’re craving something red…you head to the Italian Alps of Valle d’Aosta…a cool Alpine finish in the shadow of the mountains, wrapped in the earthy, rose-scented embrace of Nebbiolo. But alas, you’re not in Italy. So instead, we’re pouring the wines and taking the trip with you—one glass at a time. 7/22 through 7/27 - Chilled Summer Reds The only thing that gives me the Summertime Blues is not being able to have my reds. But wait! Get ready to ditch your sauvy bee and rosé for some mindblowing chilled reds that will light your next bbq on fire! This week we are pouring a GSM blend [Grenache/Syrah/Mourvèdre] from Languedoc-Roussillon in Southern Rhône that is fresh and fruity, a silky Gamay from one of the ten famed Beaujolais cru regions, Saint-Amour, and the most interesting Malbec I've ever had that is perfect for your backyard BBQ this weekend! 7/15 through 7/20 - Skin Contact Wines By now you've likely heard the buzz term 'Orange Wine', but what the heck is it? Simply put, Orange wine is to White wine, what Rosé is to Red. It's just wine that sits on the skins for a short amount of time. Typically white wine is made by pressing grapes to extract the juice, which is then fermented without the skins. In skin contact winemaking, white grape juice is left in contact with the skins for an extended period during fermentation. This extended contact period, called maceration, allows the juice to absorb color, tannins, and other flavor compounds from the skins. The longer the maceration, the more intense the color and flavor of the resulting wine. This can range from a golden hue to an orange or amber color. Skin contact introduces tannins to the white wine, which are typically found in red wines and can give the wine a more textured, sometimes slightly bitter, mouthfeel. Skin contact wines can have a wider range of aromas and flavors than traditional white wines, including notes of stone fruit, orange peel, white flowers, and sometimes even earthy or herbal characteristics. In essence, skin contact wines offer a unique taste experience that is distinct from both traditional white and red wines, bridging the gap between the two. ​7/8 through 7/13 - So Fresh and So Green, Green There's nothing I love more in the Summertime than a fresh white wine on a hot day. My go-to's are usually something with high acid, like an adult lemonade, or floral aromatics that remind me of honeysuckle blooms, or a hint of effervesence like a poolside spritz. This week we are highlighting 3 brand new wines on our menu, including a citrusy, dry Riesling from Mosel, Germany, an aromatic bouquet from the Vinho Verde Alvariñho blend, and a Verdejo from Spain that finishes with a kiss of bubbles. Click on the 'Flight of the Week' link above for more details. 7/1 through 7/6 - Red, White, and Blue Fruit In honor of our great country's 249th anniversary this week, we are celebrating our way with red, white, and blue, fresh and fruity wines! Fruity doesn't necessarily mean sweet, though...more like juicy and thirstquenching [think fresh, plump blueberries versus a sweetened blueberry pie]. All week long, and for only $17 per flight of 3, we are sampling a Sauvignon Blanc from Sonoma, rosé of Touriga Nacional from Douro, and GSM red blend [Grenache, Syrah, Mourvedrè]! June Flight of the Month - Brosé This June, we’re celebrating Father’s Day early and all month long the only way that makes sense: with four bone-dry French rosés that crush stereotypes harder than a gym bro on leg day. Whether your dad’s a grill master, a wine snob, or just really into ‘not asking for directions,’ this flight proves pink wine can mow lawns and tell bad dad jokes. We are kicking the flight off on Tuesday, June 3rd at 6pm with our favorite Francophile, Ricky Glass, who lead us on a journey through Champagne in December. He is going to dive deep into the different processes used to make rosé, the iconic regions they hail from, and the stylistic nuances you’ll know to look for. 6/24 through 6/29 - Fresh New Summer Wines It seems like the weather shifted from rainy spring afternoons to summer scorchers overnight and we are ready for these hot days! From a fresh Croatian white, to an Orange/Skin Contact blended wine from Willamette Valley, and then finishing with a juicy red Grenache blend from Rhône, no matter what you prefer when your mouth runs dry, we've got your hydration covered this week. Click on the 'Flight of the Week' link above for more details. 6/17 through 6/22 - Five Years, A Celebration of 2020 All week long we are celebrating our 2020 inception with 2020 wines. Every day we will share incredibly special wines that have been shared with us along the way. The flight will be 3 individual wines, and will only last as long as the bottle does [that’s right…only one bottle of each]. While they may a secret to you now, trust that this week is VERY special to us and the wines will be too. How do you put into words what we’ve built together over the last five years? I can’t, so I have to let the pictures do the talking for me. From Expert Tastings to NY NYE PJ Parties, Birthdays, Engagements, Weddings, Awards, Babies, Covid and whatever else life through at us!….we did it all, and we did it together as a community. Thank you from the bottom of mine, Jarrett, and all of our Doxie’s hearts, for helping us build our bar, our community, and most importantly, our friendships. We have loved every minute of it. Here’s to the next five years! May Flight of the Month - Mauro Molino, Barolo Producer in Piedmont This month we are enjoying one of our favorite summertime reds, Nebbiolo and it's richer twin sister, Barolo. Mauro Molino is one of the most respected Barolo producers and has some of the most prized properties in all of Piedmont. You will taste a Langhe Nebbiolo, Barolo produced from many of their coveted single vineyards, and a single vineyard from Bricco Luciano. Make it a true experience by adding on a food pairing that includes three cheeses, three meats, and an array of accoutrements, all from Piedmont. Azienda Agricola Mauro Molino is a 12 hectare estate located in the commune of La Morra. They claim holdings in some of La Morra’s most storied vineyards: Gattera, Bricco Luciani, Conca and Gallinotto. The family has owned the farm since 1953. Mauro was the first to estate bottle his family production in 1978 and his first Barolo came in 1982. Now Mauro’s son, Matteo and daughter, Martina are taking on a large role in the estate. La Morra is on the soft side of Barolo, the western side, it has bluish soils of chalk and calcareous clay that are mixed with sand which are more fertile than soils on the Eastern side. The farm is located at the lower eastern side of the La Morra hill, in the hamlet of Annunziata. Annunziata is a sub-section of La Morra and is where the Conca vineyard is located. 5/27 through 6/1 - Unoaked Chardonnay: because not all grapes need to be smothered in butter and applause It feels like Chardonnay has been getting a bad wrap lately, and it’s mostly due to a certain domestic style we’ve mistakenly associated with the entire population of the grape. But not all Chardonnay was created equal. In the style of the Francophiles, we are celebrating the bright, fresh, and zippy chards for Old World wine lovers this week and offering 3 samples this week from around the world that will definitely make you wish you didn’t underestimate it for so long. 5/20 through 5/25 - Nebbiolo in Tre Modi 🇮🇹 Explore Langhe’s iconic grape in three expressions: 🌹 G.D. Vajra Rosato – bright, floral, and ultra-refreshing 🍒 Mauro Molino Langhe Nebbiolo – juicy red fruit with soft charm 🖤 G.D. Vajra Langhe Nebbiolo – structured, earthy, and classically dry Three faces of Nebbiolo. One flight. Pure Langhe soul. 5/06 through 5/11 - Screw Caps Let’s clear up a few misconceptions surrounding the idea of screw top wines. For starters, a wine with a screw cap does not immediately mean that the wine is of a lower quality. Wines bottled with a screw cap can be just as high quality or even higher quality than some wines bottled with a cork, and the screw cap technology grows every day to improve the bottling process. Another myth is that screw cap wines cannot be aged like a corked wine. While a screw cap allows for less oxygen to enter the bottle, this does not mean that the wine cannot age at all. In addition, new screw cap designs are coming out every day that allow users to control the amount of oxygen that can get into the bottle, offering greater control over the aging process. Winemakers adopted screw tops to ensure a more reliable seal, reduce the risk of cork taint, and offer consumers a more convenient wine experience. April Flight of the Month - Dry Creek Vineyards, Sonoma County On Thursday, April 3rd at 6pm, we will have the honor and privilege of hosting Dry Creek Vineyards President, Kim Stare Wallace 💃🏻 Her father, David Stare, founded this famed vineyard and winery in 1952, and mentored Kim throughout her lifetime. She is showing two whites, Chenin Blanc and Fumé Blanc [aka Sauv Blanc] and two reds, Zinfandel blend and Cabernet Sauvignon blend. This is a wonderful opportunity to meet a legend in the industry in an intimate setting with great wine and food! Additionally, all of Kim’s wines will be an additional 30% off, this night only. Price per person includes a meet and greet with Kim, and wine and cheese pairing. March Flight of the Month - Catalonia, Spain Discover the bold, terroir-driven wines of Spanish Owner/Winemaker, Jordi Masdeu Català! Next Tuesday 2/25 at 6pm, Jordi is joining us at Vin Rouge Wine Bar and sharing 4 wines from 2 of his projects. Jordi crafts expressive, terroir-driven wines that showcase the depth of Spanish viticulture. We will sample his vibrant L’Atzar Cava that sparkles with crisp citrus and fine bubbles during the meet and greet. Then you’ll be invited to sit down for a Q+A while you enjoy his Mas La Mola Trepat that delights with its fresh red fruit and elegant spice, Expressió Priorat that is bold and complex, layered with dark fruit, mineral depth, and silky tannins, and Vi d’Altura that captures the purity of high-altitude vineyards, offering bright acidity, floral aromatics, and refined structure. Each bottle tells a story of place, passion, and precision. 3/25 through 3/29 - Obscure Varietals This is always one of our favorite flights. We love to share these lesser known wines with you so your knowledge can grow beyond the basics and you can stretch outside of your comfort zone. This week we are shining the spotlight on Verdicchio from Marche, Italy, Clairette from Southern Rhône, and Xarel-lo from Penedès, Spain. The tasting is only $18 and when you fall in love with one or all, you can get additional glasses or bottles to go, for 20% off [must purchase flight in order to receive the discount]. 3/18 through 3/22 - Fresh French Wines [aka f*ck the tariffs] The threat of tariffs on EU wines has us feeling all kind of feels and giving zero effs. We will not allow politics to get in the way of the wines we love! This week we are featuring 3 beautiful, classic French wines including a gorgeous Chardonnay and Gamay from newer, boutique Burgundian producer Nicolas Delfaud, and dry and delicate Grenache rosé from Provence. 3/11 through 3/15 - Fresh Italian Wines Who doesn’t love this time of year? Whether you are an extrovert through-and-through and can’t wait to get back out into the living, breathing world again, or slightly introverted and can’t wait to get your garden planned and planted, this time of year feels like a rebirth, inspiring you to get out of your winter funk. We’ve been inspired by this glimpse of spring to revamp our menu for the new season, and there’s no better place than Italy to look to for inspiration for these flavors. Vermentino is the perfect springtime wine, with its crisp acidity, bright citrus notes, and refreshing minerality. Grown primarily in coastal regions like Sardinia [like Bagella], Liguria, and Tuscany, this aromatic white wine bursts with flavors of lemon, green apple, and subtle floral hints, making it an ideal match for light spring dishes like seafood, salads, and fresh herbs. As the weather warms and outdoor dining returns, a chilled glass of Vermentino embodies the essence of the season—vibrant, breezy, and effortlessly enjoyable. Strawberries and Cream [in the best, not-sweet-but-fruity, kind of way]! This Rosé of Nebbiolo offers a unique balance of elegance and structure, making it a standout choice for spring and summer. Known for its vibrant acidity and delicate floral aromas, this rosé often showcases notes of wild strawberries, citrus, and rose petals, with a hint of Nebbiolo’s signature minerality and tannic grip. Frappato is a bright, aromatic red wine from Sicily, known for its juicy red fruit flavors, floral notes, and light-bodied elegance. With vibrant acidity and soft tannins, it bursts with flavors of strawberries, cherries, and a touch of spice, making it an incredibly fresh and food-friendly wine. Often enjoyed slightly chilled, Frappato is a perfect choice for warm-weather sipping or casual gatherings where a lively, easy-drinking red is needed. February Flight of the Month - Pedro Parra y Familia from Valle de Itata, Chile On Tuesday February 4th, one of our favorite wine experts, Ben Stewart with @giulianawinecompany is going to lead us through a tasting of Chilean wines from the Dr. of Dirt, Pedro Parra. That’s right…Pedro is one of the few people in the world to hold a PhD in Terroir and is one of the most highly sought after consultants in the world because of his knowledge. These light but luscious reds will include the 'Soulpit' País, 'Imaginador' Cinsault, and Pedro’s reserve Cinsault, 'Newt'. All of these beauties are from what Pedro has said is his favorite Valle de Itata vintage, 2021, and I have to agree because 2021 has definitely shown to be one of our favorites too. Once again, St. Kilian’s has put together the perfect pairing of cheeses and meat to accompany so if you want to geek out with us on some seriously geeky wines, book your reservation on OpenTable before all of these beauties spots fill up. And the whole private experience is only $45 per person! What are you waiting for? 2/25 through 3/1 - Fresh New Whites This unseasonably beautiful weather has got us craving some fresh and fruity whites! This week we are featuring a Sauvignon Blanc from Cheverny, Loire alongside a Petit-Chablis and an acid-ripping Riesling from the Rogue Valley in Oregon. Enjoy the whole flight for only $20! Pairs well with our French cheese board too. 2/18 through 2/22 - Que Syrah Syrahhhh! This week we are paying homage to one of our favorite grapes on the planet…syrahhhh. Join us for a flight of three different examples from the Central Coast and get 20% off their flight, glasses and bottles. 2/11 through 2/15 - Celebrate Love! Love is in the air! And we want to celebrate all week long with you, your girlfriends, your significant others, and all of your loved ones! So in addition to our normal wines by the glass and bottle, we are offering a few very special wines for this very special occasion alongside chocolate and/or cheese pairings. One of the beauties is a Cremant from Chablis that is a Rosé of Pinot Noir from esteemed producer Patrick Piuze. It is refreshingly fruity but dry, with notes of strawberries and cream. I snagged a few bottles of this incredible ‘Saint Amour’ Gamay, named for the famous region it hails from in Beaujolais. This beautiful lady is elegant but bright, smells of fresh strawberries and violets, and absolute perfection. Because we 🫶🏻 you, we brought in this exceptional Pinot for our ‘célébration de l’amour’, from Michel Gay, in Côte-de-Beaune in Burgundy. 1/27 through 2/2 - Sabor de España Spain produces some of the most iconic wines in the world, and at a fraction of the cost of some of its neighbors. This week we are featuring a handful of those indigenous varietals, including an iconic Albariño alongside relatively unknown Trepat and its more famous counterpart, Garnacha. Join Our Mailing List! The ACCJ and TJCS The ACCJ is a non-profit membership organization committed to further developing commerce between the United States of America and Japan, promoting the interests of U.S. companies and members, and improving the international business environment in Japan. The ACCJ is driven by its approximately 3,500 members from over 1,000 companies and 40 countries. The ACCJ Chubu Chapter was established in 2000, it stands out as the hub for Nagoya business among the American and greater international communities. www.accj.or.jp Similar to the ACCJ, the TJCS (Tokai Japan Canada Society) has a mandate to strengthen ties between the Tokai region of Japan and Canada through business, social and cultural events. Both organizations strive to create a sense of community among all foreigner nationals and internationally-minded Japanese in the region.
